Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing a wide range of phenomena. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This is partly because it is a non-classical theory, in the sense that it does not fit into the classical framework of logic and set theory. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach provides a framework in which the mathematical structure of quantum theory is transparent and easy to understand.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genome assembly of a myxozoan parasite and compare it to the genome of a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century. Meeting the food demand of this population will become increasingly challenging as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and digestive physiology, LMH consumed different plant species and that their diets differed substantially. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the importance of plant diversity in determining the extent to which LMH partition food resources. This finding is particularly important in light of the widespread loss of plant diversity in many parts of the world.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and they are concerned about accessing the CARES Act loans. We also find that businesses that receive loans are more likely to be able to maintain their operations and pay their workers.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks, which involve a combination of nano-fragmentation of the plastic, its transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The origin of the solar system is a central topic in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the planets and the origin of the solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. The grains are part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains have ages that are older than the formation of the solar system. This indicates that the solar system is not the oldest place in the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

In contrast, in many other species, including many mammals, the ability to reproduce is limited by the availability of resources. Here, we show that the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power in placental mammals. We also show that the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power in many other species, including many mammals. This suggests that the evolution of reproduction may be a universal feature of life. Our results suggest that the evolution of reproduction may be a universal feature of life.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to preserve their function in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA and to improve the quality of life of patients.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling vascular function, including hemostasis, inflammation, and oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that receives and integrates information from multiple sources. This information is processed and coordinated by a network of cells that are connected to each other. The network is surprisingly complex and has been difficult to study. Here, we use a combination of imaging and mathematical modeling to study the network of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. We find that the network is small-world, which means that it is both efficient at transmitting information locally and globally. The network is also highly connected, which means that it is robust to damage. These findings reveal the design principles of the endothelial network and provide insights into how it controls cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This coupling is mediated by an allosteric mechanism, which is triggered by the opening of the activation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this Threonine residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and that its substitution with Alanine leads to the loss of C-type inactivation gating and to an inversion of the allosteric coupling. Finally, we have provided a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in health and disease. The role of the anaerobic gut fungi in the microbiome is not well understood. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and antimicrobials that are unique to anaerobic fungi. These results support the idea that anaerobic gut fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the microbiome and may have therapeutic applications. It is characterized by a high risk of developing social avoidance and social withdrawal, which can lead to social isolation and loneliness. The brain region that is most strongly implicated in social behavior is the nucleus accumbens (NAc), which is also the focus of this study. We show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this is mediated by reduced mitochondrial function in the NAc. We further demonstrate that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious rats. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the NAc as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a digital synthesis approach to synthesize multifunctional structures with multiple material phases that seamlessly collaborate to produce desired behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, which is based on the principle of the least constraint energy. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which is based on the principle of the least material volume. The structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work is expected to inspire the design of multifunctional structures with complex behaviors and to provide a general strategy for the fabrication of multifunctional devices.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is highly variable in adults, and the cause of this variability is unknown. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) mediates the developmental silencing of hemoglobin expression in human erythrocytes. This finding has implications for the understanding of the developmental origin of hemoglobin expression in adults and suggests a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. The most common cause of cancer-related death is the inability of cancer cells to die by a programmed form of cell death, called apoptosis. This inability is due to the ability of cancer cells to activate survival pathways that prevent apoptosis. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which is required for the development of vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings may help to explain the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted clearcutting on federal land, but that the policy has not yet reversed declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area was stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management in policy evaluation.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and that it is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity against three of the most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our results suggest that the design strategy is a promising approach for the development of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The Lake Malawi region is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth, and the lake is a critical component of the global hydrological cycle. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability from Lake Malawi. The record shows dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The record also shows evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. The record also shows that the lake was often overfilled during the last 1.3 My, indicating a climate wetter than today. This wetness was interrupted by prolonged intervals of extreme drought. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the amount of sleep. These effects are similar to those of reading a printed book, suggesting that the light emitted by these devices may be responsible for the observed effects. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climate event that has been attributed to a bolide impact. However, the origin of the magnetic grains and microspherules that are a characteristic of the YDB is still debated. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are terrestrial in origin and that the 187Os/188Os ratios of the grains and microspherules are consistent with the Os in average upper continental crust. The Os in the magnetic grains and microspherules is likely derived from the impact event.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the adult is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the adult, but not in the fetus. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency has opposing effects on different autoimmune models.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We propose that horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable efficient digestion of plant cell walls, including lignocellulose, triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles, resulting in nearly half of all living beetle species. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of beetles and their symbionts, and may have implications for the evolution of other animals and plants.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies may help to elucidate the pathophysiology of APOE4 and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the core material, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, which is different from the crystallization scenario. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving.

Language is the most complex behavior we know. How the human brain processes language is a central question in cognitive science. We here show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can predict brain responses to sentences in the human brain, and that this predictive processing is correlated with behavioral performance. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the brain may use predictive coding to solve the language comprehension task. This is a major step forward in our understanding of the brain’s signature cognitive skill.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, including computer vision, speech recognition, and natural language processing. However, it has been shown to be unstable, and it is not clear how to train a stable deep network. We show that the instability of deep learning is closely related to the existence of stable deep networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where there exist stable deep networks, but there is no algorithm that can train such a network. This result provides a classification theory of the conditions under which stable deep networks can be trained. We also introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENET), that is stable and converges fast. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of deep learning in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper shows that the “perfect storm” is an overstatement. The classic experiment that is often cited as evidence for the “failure to understand exponential growth” has a number of critical design flaws. These flaws were not noticed at the time of the experiment, and the flaws are not mentioned in the literature. The flaws are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, where leprosy is endemic, and found that it is closely related to the leprosy pathogen, but not to other Mycobacterium species. This finding suggests that the two pathogens have diverged from a common ancestor and that the ancient separation of the two pathogens has not prevented them from causing similar pathologic conditions.

The evolution of entanglement is a key question in quantum information science and a fundamental problem in statistical physics. It is also of great interest for condensed-matter physics, where entanglement is a key resource for quantum technologies. In this work, we study the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic Heisenberg spin chain. We show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a consequence of integrability. This result is a major step toward a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been devastating, and the search for a vaccine is ongoing. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated, yet retains the ability to infect cells and induce robust immune responses. This vaccine candidate is promising because it is large-scale manufacturable, has a single intranasal dose, and is protective in a relevant hamster model. This vaccine candidate could be used in mass vaccination programs to achieve herd immunity.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with some studies suggesting that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-vector interactions in the epidemiology of infectious diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in neuroscience, but the evolution of brain numbers is still poorly understood. This study shows that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the utility of TRAP1 as a target for cancer therapy is unclear because of the lack of specific TRAP1 inhibitors. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell migration, cytokinesis, and vesicle trafficking. However, the molecular mechanisms that underlie ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever actin filaments are not well understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever actin filaments is enhanced by a mechanical torque. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a molecular explanation for how ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever actin filaments is enhanced in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress. Our findings also suggest that this mechanism could be used to design new types of biomaterials that are able to sever themselves upon contact with cells. This article is protected by copyright. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake. They also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results may also have implications for understanding the effects of fasting versus feeding on brain and behavior. Finally, the findings suggest that fructose may be a more potent contributor to the metabolic syndrome than previously thought. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, as we found that the settlement was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations from Africa and Asia. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a step forward in our understanding of the history of the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This finding has implications for the design of social networks, as it suggests that people may be influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not interacting with them in person. It also suggests that people may be influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not interacting with them in person. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of chemical modifications in the sequence of mRNAs has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has only recently been appreciated. We show that the most common modification in mRNA coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence and can also alter the rate of translation. These findings have implications for the function of mRNAs in cells and suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions may be a mechanism by which cells can modulate translation. Our study also highlights the importance of considering the impact of chemical modifications on protein synthesis when studying the function of mRNAs. This work is important for understanding the function of mRNAs in cells and may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling protein synthesis in vivo.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including better social and health outcomes. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has been hypothesized to drive the evolution of larger body sizes, but the extent to which this is the case has not been tested quantitatively. We use a model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. This model is consistent with the evolution of larger body sizes in all four extant aquatic mammal lineages.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more robust antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C, which correlates with higher levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings suggest that rhinovirus exploits the cooler temperature of the nasal cavity to evade the antiviral defense response of infected cells and to initiate infection. The results also suggest that the antiviral defense response of infected cells may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of the common cold. This study also provides a model for studying the temperature-dependent growth of other viruses.

The type IV pili (T4P) of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are involved in a wide range of biological processes, including biofilm formation and pathogenicity. In this study, we show that T4P are also used by P. aeruginosa as a sensor for surface attachment. This results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment and virulence. Our results suggest that T4P are a mechanochemical sensor that measures the mechanical activity of the pili, and that this mechanochemical signal is amplified by a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term surface attachment. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of pili as both adhesins and sensors. It also has implications for the design of antimicrobial strategies against P. aeruginosa, as the pili-mediated surface attachment is a key virulence factor that is essential for the pathogen to colonize the host. This study thus provides a unique example of how pili are used by bacteria as a sensor for environmental signals.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus responsible for the disease, SARS-CoV-2, has been detected in a variety of animal species. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human infections are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and suggest that a “One Health” approach is needed to understand the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a proactive approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ deposits and cell death. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of mounting an inflammatory response in response to Aβ. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of cytokines that mobilize microglia, and that this response is vulnerable in the human brain. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the inflammatory response that leads to neuronal death and the formation of amyloid plaques in AD. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may be a vulnerability in the human brain that contributes to the disease progression. Our findings may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was practiced there as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of folding at high resolution in a single experiment. We used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein that folds in two steps. The first step is a fast collapse into a polyglobular state, which is followed by a slower step that forms a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is a prerequisite for folding to the native state. These results are important for understanding the folding process and for the design of new proteins with desired folding properties. They also suggest that the intermediate is not a single structure but a family of structures that are close in energy.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for rapid degradation of the capped transcripts. The predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study reveals a mechanism for how a bacterial stress response can be hijacked to alter the decay rate of a specific class of transcripts.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We found that citrulline, an amino acid that is converted to arginine in the body, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are a step forward in understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, despite external perturbations. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, a critical behavior, and a self-healing property. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its electronic bandgap can be opened, by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the health of the host is well established. However, the role of the host in the health of the microbiota is less understood. In this study, we show that the host plant can protect itself against fungal pathogens by producing a structurally unique antifungal peptide. This peptide, which is expressed in nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula, is highly diverse in sequence and exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of this peptide against fungal pathogens is unique and involves the disruption of the fungal cell wall and the disruption of the cell membrane. This work provides a unique example of how the host plant can protect itself against fungal pathogens. It also provides a structural basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of life. The male–female axis is also a model for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of life. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the male–female axis is a dynamic system in which sperm undergo a series of compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins are initially associated with sperm and become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular hand-off between males and females. (Abridged)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the pathophysiology of VWD. The force-induced conformational change is reversible, with the same force that converts the receptor to the second state also inducing a state with slower off-rate. The force-induced changes in VWF are quantitatively similar to those in the bulk phase, suggesting that the force-induced changes are important for the function of VWF. This work provides a mechanism for the effects of mutations in VWF. It also provides a quantitative description of the effects of force on biological systems. This work is important for understanding the effects of force on biological systems. It also provides a quantitative description of the effects of force on biological systems.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study overcomes this obstacle, and provides a resource for the study of viruses in the microbiome. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results suggest that viruses may play a more important role in human health than previously thought.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a complex process that is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. We introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is lower than that inferred from protein evidence. This discrepancy has been attributed to a variety of factors, including the possibility that the isotopic record may have been reset by diagenesis or metamorphism. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. The results obtained from ancestral enzymes are consistent with the temperature inferred from isotopic evidence. This study demonstrates the utility of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insights into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. They are also involved in a variety of diseases, including arrhythmia. The K+ channel KCNJ10 is mutated in long QT syndrome, a disease characterized by abnormal heart rhythm. We studied the K+ channel KCNMA1, which is mutated in long-QT syndrome type 2. We found that the KCNMA1 channel has two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We propose that the KCNMA1 channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a framework for understanding the function of K+ channels and their diseases. It also provides a basis for the development of new drugs for arrhythmia. The malaria parasite must invade the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle and cause disease. The parasite uses a variety of mechanisms to facilitate invasion, including the binding of its adhesin, EBA175, to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface. Here, we show that EBA175 binding alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work also provides a potential target for the development of new antimalarial drugs.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. It is therefore important to understand the limits of its mechanical stability. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, and that its bandgap can be made direct through strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the limits of mechanical stability of diamond. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity condition are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We found that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease outcome in the context of ambient humidity. They also suggest that humidity may be a potential target for the development of influenza vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to involve a tree-like structure of nested phrases, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we used intracranial recordings to show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with the hypothesis that the brain first builds phrases and then merges them into larger structures. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our findings may help to elucidate the neural basis of sentence processing and may have implications for the design of language-based brain-computer interfaces.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is important for development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work is important for understanding the evolution of redundant genes and their regulation. It also provides a model for the evolution of redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. It is known that stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, but the circuit elements that mediate this effect are not known. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat for the remainder of the 60-s stimulation period. We also show that this effect is blocked by lesions of the ventral tegmental area, substantia nigra, and peri-locus coeruleus neurons, suggesting that these are the main circuit elements that mediate this effect. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in the regulation of normal feeding.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural regions. Nitrogen fixation is a sustainable and efficient way to deliver nitrogen to plants, but the symbiosis is difficult to control and often fails to deliver nitrogen to the plant. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the nitrogen fixation symbiosis in barley, using a bacterial signal to activate or deactivate the symbiosis. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signaling molecule in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, but it is also one of the most threatened. The region is experiencing the highest rates of deforestation in the world, and the rate of deforestation is increasing. The Amazon is also home to 200 million people, many of whom depend on the forest for their livelihoods. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the program may have unintended effects. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in shape and size, but all are part of the animal’s body. Here, we show that the ears of the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius are not constrained by the organism’s body but are extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is used to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider supersizes its auditory surface area by outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, which provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides insights into the evolution of sensing and design of artificial sensory systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The health benefits are substantial, and the climate benefits are large, too. The climate benefits are masked by aerosols, but removing them liberates the climate benefits. The health benefits are also masked by ozone, but reducing it moderates the warming. The health and climate benefits are additive, and the benefits are larger than the costs.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) lack access to vaccines. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that is well-suited for inclusion in subunit vaccines. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern, and presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This variant could be included in subunit vaccines to increase global access to COVID-19 vaccines. This work provides a potential solution to the global distribution of COVID-19 vaccines.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We demonstrate that zebrafish ALK homologs are activated by secreted ALKAL proteins and that the resulting signaling events are required for the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALK-related RTKs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and suggest a role of ALKALs in the development of human cancers.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in humans is a well-known historical event, but the details of its evolution are still largely unknown. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the evolution of this pathogen during the formative years of its emergence. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic was already present in the Eurasian Late Neolithic, and that the pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps that led to its adaptation to fleas. This study also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its adaptation to its vector, which are crucial for understanding the origins of this disease. They also provide a valuable resource for studying the evolution of pathogens in the past. (Abridged)

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is associated with men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump. This finding is consistent with the idea that HM is a cultural ideology that legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies. The findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of HM, including the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question in the context of climate change. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil, but the extent to which these practices increase SOC storage in the subsoil remains unknown. We found that soil health management practices increased SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil, but the extent to which these practices increased SOC storage in the subsoil was highly variable. These results highlight the importance of subsoil SOC in the context of climate-smart agriculture and the need for further research to understand the fate of subsoil SOC in agricultural systems. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for spillover and developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The top-ranking viruses were known zoonotic viruses, but several newly discovered viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators is nectar, which is produced by specialized glands in the flower. Nectar is a sweet liquid that contains carbohydrates, amino acids, and vitamins. The color of nectar is often yellow or orange, but some flowers produce red nectar. We show that the red color of Nesocodon mauritianus nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid called nesocodin. We also show that the red color of hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae nectar is also derived from nesocodin. This work demonstrates that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red color is a favored trait and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new compound for the study of nectar chemistry and the identification of potential pollinators. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–8th centuries AD) is poorly understood. We present a genome-wide analysis of a sample of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for developing effective countermeasures against future zoonotic outbreaks. This article is

The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating the spread of emerging and reemerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based platform to sequence pathogen RNA from 464 febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. This study demonstrates that pathogen-agnostic metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a blueprint for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This study also highlights the importance of a global cloud-based platform for pathogen surveillance.

The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication fork progression. This process is driven by the activity of the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) enzyme. The activity of pol δ is tightly regulated by the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The activity of pol δ is also tightly regulated by the DNA damage checkpoint. In this study, we use a combination of biochemical and biophysical techniques to study the activity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We find that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and that the stability of the holoenzyme is not dependent on the activity of the sliding clamp. We also find that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more processive than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and that the processivity of the holoenzyme is dependent on the activity of the sliding clamp. Finally, we find that the human pol δ holoenzyme dissociates from the sliding clamp more rapidly on encountering a DNA lesion than on encountering a mismatch.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it has been possible to evolve ribozymes that can catalyze the replication of RNA, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can both replicate RNA and synthesize functional RNA molecules. Here, we report the successful evolution of such a ribozyme.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in areas that are densely populated by college-educated adults and that are physically attractive. These results have implications for urban planning and for the design of computer vision methods for urban studies.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical patients are similar, and the mortality rate is high. The immune characteristics of patients with severe and critical COVID-19 are not clear. We have identified that the immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. The results provide a reference for the clinical treatment of severe and critical COVID-19. Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its toxicity is a major cause of disease in humans and animals. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes is not. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC-derived isocyanide metabolites of Aspergillus fumigatus bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These results suggest that the xan BGC is a source of natural products that impact copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study also demonstrates the utility of the CAS assay for visualizing and measuring the binding of metal isocyanides to copper. This assay can be used to identify additional fungal natural products that bind metal ions.

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery. The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2. Plagioclase (∼17 wt.% of bulk sample), tridymite (∼14 wt.%), sanidine (∼3 wt.%), cation-deficient magnetite (∼3 wt.%), cristobalite (∼2 wt.%), and anhydrite (∼1 wt.%) are the mudstone crystalline minerals. Amorphous material is silica-rich (∼39 wt.% opal-A and/or high-SiO2 glass and opal-CT), volatile-bearing (16 wt.% mixed cation sulfates, phosphates, and chlorides−perchlorates−chlorates), and has minor TiO2 and Fe2O3T oxides

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in response to climate warming, and that trees are evolving to minimize frost damage. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear whether Th17 cells are required for disease or whether they are merely a component of the inflammatory response. We found that Th17 cells were required for the development of colitis, and that they were able to provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in many genes, but the cause of the disease in most patients is unknown. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease in a disease-specific manner. This method will also enable high-throughput screening of drugs to identify those that alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. This study is a step forward in the fight against ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of the microbiota in infectious disease is becoming increasingly clear, but the ways in which pathogens influence the composition of the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector tick Ixodes scapularis to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data provide a mechanistic framework for the role of the microbiota in infectious disease and vector competence. They also suggest that the microbiota may be a potential target for the control of vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that includes the modern bird family Pygostylia. However, the diversity of early branching members of this group is limited, obscuring our understanding of the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One of the most difficult aspects of the climate system is its sensitivity to changes in greenhouse gases. We show here that the climate system is also sensitive to changes in water vapor in the stratosphere. This is significant because water vapor is the most important greenhouse gas.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, including blue-green. This phenomenon, called chlorosis, is thought to be due to the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a compound that is normally found in the blood. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads), and that it is due to the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, which we named biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs), are most similar to human antiproteases, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We also show that BBSs are involved in the regulation of the color of the animals. Our findings have implications for the evolution of color in vertebrates and for the understanding of the physiological basis of chlorosis.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to form tumorigenic cells, termed cancer stem cells (CSCs), is associated with poor prognosis and resistance to therapy. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which increases NANOG mRNA levels and the percentage of breast cancer cells that are tumorigenic. These effects are mediated by HIF-dependent expression of ALKBH5, which increases the expression of NANOG and the tumorigenic phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 is a mediator of the tumor microenvironment that promotes the CSC phenotype. These findings may lead to the development of therapeutic strategies to target CSCs in breast cancer.
