The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction and recovery, suggesting that the carbon cycle was not the primary trigger of the extinction. The carbon cycle was also highly volatile during the recovery, suggesting that the recovery was not rapid.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the receptor-binding domain, and the receptor-binding domain in complex with the neutralizing antibody 2G12. We find that the receptor-binding domain is in a more open conformation in the complex with 2G12, which may facilitate virus entry. We also find that the receptor-binding domain and the receptor ACE2 are in a more open conformation in the complex with the receptor-binding domain, which may facilitate virus entry. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may not have a major impact on virus infectivity.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are of fundamental importance in many fields of science. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we propose a new way of thinking about the chemical properties of atoms. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is uncertain because of the complex interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human demography, as well as climate, can have a large effect on fire activity and carbon emissions. We find that, although climate change has already warmed the global fire regime, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may offset this warming. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to consider fire in climate policy. This is especially important in the context of climate mitigation and adaptation.

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most important interactions in nature. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a classic example of this phenomenon. In this study, we show that the squid provides its symbiont with a single glycan, which is metabolized by the symbiont to enhance its ability to produce bioluminescence at night. This glycan is released by the squid’s immune cells just before dusk, a behavior that is established only in the mature symbiosis. We propose that this glycan is a nutrient that is provided and metabolized only at night, and that its provision is a mechanism by which the squid regulates the activities of its symbiont. This study highlights the importance of the timing of nutrient delivery in the evolution of symbiosis.

The study of topics in text is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent words. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be applied to many domains and is particularly useful for identifying gender biases in topics. Our method can be extended to other domains and tasks, such as topic-based clustering and topic-based summarization. It can also be used to identify topics in other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the latent patterns in text.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the Black Death was the consequence of repeated introductions of Y. pestis into European harbors, which were caused by climate-driven changes in the distribution of plague reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of a series of introductions, rather than a single introduction, and that the disease was not established in Europe until the 14th century.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for many species of marine animals. They are also a major source of food for sea stars, which are important predators in the marine ecosystem. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has been described as a mass mortality event. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis is poor. The disease is characterized by the presence of a small subpopulation of cells that are able to initiate and maintain the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are able to target and kill these cells in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that the antibodies are able to target primary human AML cells, suggesting that they can be used in humans. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, as we found that the settlement was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations from Africa and Asia. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it has implications for the settlement of other islands in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it has implications for the settlement of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity and represses two genes involved in glycerol utilization. The protein interacts with the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and the repressor of the glycerol utilization operon. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress the genes. The protein and RNA compete for the same binding site on the repressor, suggesting that the protein and RNA have a common function.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 and other emerging viruses. This article is protected by copyright. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and difficult to aggregate. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be applied to other crops and countries, and is expected to be useful for many stakeholders in the agricultural sector.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this process. Information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neural populations. These changes are driven by the intrinsic activity of the neurons and are not dependent on synaptic plasticity or persistent activity. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features together over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at single sites, and there is a need for a global synthesis of the effects of climate warming on soil respiration. We present the largest global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements to date, and provide a global perspective on the effects of climate warming on soil respiration. Our results provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our results highlight the need for further research to understand the effects of climate warming on soil respiration. This information is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of plastids is a key event in the evolution of eukaryotes, as they are the site of photosynthesis and the origin of the nucleus. The evolution of plastid genomes is also of great interest because of their role in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The evolution of plastid genomes is shaped by the functional constraints imposed by their position in the cell, and by the evolutionary history of the host cell. Here, we show that the evolution of plastid genomes is shaped by the evolution of the host cell, and that the evolution of the host cell is shaped by the evolution of plastids.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was the first in a series of consecutive dry winters in southwestern South Africa. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of the South African water system for the global climate. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, released more energy in 1 second than the sun will in 3.5 billion years. The explosion created a blast wave that spread a glassy material called trinitite, which contains the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. The discovery of this material provides a unique link between the past and the present, and it demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed by extreme pressure–temperature conditions that are common in nature and in industry.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring, the cyclase reaction, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. AcsF is the cyclase in R. gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein, BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process involving multiple signaling pathways, including mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) signaling. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a MAP3K that has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased substantially. These findings are consistent with the expectation that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of drought in California. This finding is important because it suggests that the probability of drought will continue to increase in the future, even if global warming is not as rapid as in the past. This conclusion is important for water managers, policy makers, and the public because the probability of drought will continue to increase in the future, even if global warming is not as rapid as in the past.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This finding provides a mechanistic understanding of the core autistic symptoms and opens up a new avenue for the development of treatments for autism. This article is protected by copyright. The news media are a powerful force in our lives, and the content they produce is often the primary source of information for the general public. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present in a wide variety of countries and cultures. The results also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content, suggesting that the conventional wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads” may not be entirely accurate.

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of critical cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the SO channel protein ORAI1 or in the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and muscle dysfunction, respectively. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO channel signaling, suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions, and advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO channel. This study also highlights the importance of functional studies in patients with Stormorken syndrome, which is a rare disease with a high unmet medical need. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that aggregates spread in a non–cell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates. These results provide a model for the study of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that this protein, named MTX, is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit leukotriene B4 (LTB4) generation and the antiviral immune response. MTX exacerbated influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity in mice, and this effect was reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of zoonotic viruses from bats.

Cancer cells have a number of metabolic vulnerabilities, and one-carbon metabolism is a promising target. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and that dual inhibition of SHMT1/2 is a promising strategy for cancer therapy. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, and show that it is effective in cancer cells and in xenograft tumors. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. Thus, formate is a promising metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells. These results have implications for cancer therapy and for the design of metabolic vulnerabilities. They also suggest that formate may be a promising drug target in cancer. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the neuropathology of ALS and suggests that the disease is caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a better understanding of the evolution of the flowering plants. The study of Montsechia has shown that the origin of the flowering plants was not in a forest habitat but in an aquatic habitat. This opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the evolution of the flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) and show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we find a substitution rate that is an order of magnitude lower than inferred previously. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. This is important for understanding the history of human–virus interactions. It also has implications for the evolution of the virus and the origin of genotype 2.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we use a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data to estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level. We find that the acceleration is statistically significant and is consistent with the acceleration of many other geophysical and biogeochemical processes. We also find that the rate of sea level rise is increasing, which is consistent with the findings of other studies. These results suggest that the rate of sea level rise is also likely to increase in the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. This pattern is not seen for those with a bachelor’s degree, suggesting that the erosion of working-class life is having a negative impact on the health of tomorrow’s elderly.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity that is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology and highlights the potential of this approach for the study of other enzyme active sites.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the disease has a high mortality rate. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses. This study also highlights the importance of continued research on the development of antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most complex and diverse interactions in nature. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host squid Euprymna scolopes to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a critical factor in the dynamic stability of the mutualism. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, in which the provision of a single nutrient, in this case chitin, is sufficient to maintain a dynamic symbiosis. This study also highlights the importance of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate effects on students of color and students with disabilities. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The intervention is simple and inexpensive, and it has the potential to reduce suspensions and improve the quality of teacher–student relationships.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription machinery can recognize and bypass alkylated DNA lesions. We also found that the transcription machinery can recognize and bypass alkylated DNA lesions. We also found that the transcription machinery can recognize and bypass alkylated DNA lesions. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. This requirement for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria increased the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals by 40% and had no detectable rebound effect. These results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could make a significant contribution to reducing the environmental and health impacts of the food system. This approach could be applied in other settings, including hospitals, schools, and workplaces. The results also suggest that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets without the need for more complex interventions. This approach could be applied in other settings, including hospitals, schools, and workplaces. The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the effects of oncogenes on the surfaceome are not well understood. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to stably express oncogenes in a breast epithelial cell line and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is important for understanding the biology of cancer, and for the development of targeted therapies. It also provides a resource for the development of new technologies for the study of the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout and vote share in 1996 to 2018 in three states that implemented universal vote-by-mail in a staggered fashion. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout or vote share, and it modestly increases overall average turnout. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented without compromising electoral integrity.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to have a number of unique features that contribute to its rapid spread, including the ability to rapidly evolve. In this work, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, as well as a second interface that is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV. These interfaces may contribute to the unique immune evasion and evasion of interferon responses observed in SARS-CoV-2. These results provide insight into the molecular basis for the unique features of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The era of big data has led to a new challenge in statistical inference: How do we properly assess the strength of associations that we find in a large dataset? The answer depends on how we chose the dataset. We describe a new approach to selective inference that is appropriate for complex statistical models and large datasets. This approach is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the new approach with forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. These results indicate that ETV2 provides a promising strategy for the generation of ETVECs and may be used for the development of vascular networks in regenerative medicine. Furthermore, the use of ETVECs may provide a promising therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders. These findings may lead to the development of a new strategy for the treatment of ischemic disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK are important in the development of the nervous system and the immune system, respectively. In addition, two additional RTKs, ALKAL1 and ALKAL2, were recently discovered as ligands for ALK and LTK, respectively. Here, we show that zebrafish deficient in the ligands for ALK and LTK exhibit defects in the development of the iridophores, the cells that produce the eye color in zebrafish. We also show that the ligands for ALK and LTK are essential for the development of iridophores. These experiments establish a physiological link between ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 and RTK ligands and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate RTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system for the study of the physiological function of RTK ligands and their receptors. It also provides a model system for the study of the physiological function of ligands and their receptors in other organisms.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of immune response. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in β-cells, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the cause of annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process in virus replication, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. It also contributes to the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs against influenza A viruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that is initiated by the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells (ECs). The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured ECs to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This has led to substantial economic and ecological costs, and has increased the risk of wildfire to communities and infrastructure. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire to people and property should be a focus of United States policy.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in neighborhoods that are already attractive.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. We further demonstrated that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon in which corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a major driver of coral reef degradation and a major threat to the global coral reef ecosystem. We show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral host to heat stress are driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a direct consequence of the metabolic stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and that the microbiome can alter the activity of tumors. We also show that the activity of JNK signaling is important for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and for maintaining homeostasis between the host and the microbiome. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can alter the activity of tumors. This work provides insights into the mechanisms by which tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and the microbiome can alter the activity of tumors. It also provides a framework for the development of therapeutic strategies to control the activity of JNK signaling and to restore homeostasis between the host and the microbiome. Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women in the United States. Chemotherapy is the primary treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to chemotherapy is common. In this study, we found that treatment with chemotherapy increased the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 in breast cancer cells. We also found that ROR1 was expressed in breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) and that treatment of mice bearing PDXs with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab reduced the ability of the PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This study also provides a rationale for the use of cirmtuzumab in combination with chemotherapy in the treatment of patients with breast cancer. This combination therapy may be particularly effective in patients with breast cancer that has metastasized. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is difficult to reconcile with the timing of the onset of deglaciation. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, coincident with the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong El Niño-like climate event, which plausibly led to a rapid shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked in global assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our results highlight the need for improved management of inland fisheries to protect both biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide exhibits a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water, and a full cell presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the primary pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery opens the door to a new approach for identifying genes and pathways that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in sexually reproducing organisms. The distribution of recombination across genomes is highly variable, and it is unclear whether this variation is a consequence of evolutionary or developmental processes. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, and we show that the pattern of recombination is remarkably similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a complex network of functionally connected regions, which is difficult to study because of the small fraction of neuronal activity that is in a state of rest. We used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. The dominant metabolic RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects, but was subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired during rest and during task performance. Network deactivation was observed in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, and was reduced in advanced Parkinson’s disease. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. They suggest that the default mode network is a marker of healthy brain function, and that it is also a marker of disease in Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of messenger RNA (mRNA). However, there are many other modifications that have been found on mRNA, including the recently discovered 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap in bacteria. We show that NAD-mRNA is found in yeast, and that it is produced cotranscriptionally. This finding suggests that NAD-mRNA is a product of the transcription machinery and raises the possibility that it could modulate mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. The epigenetic mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not known. We used DNA methylation profiling to examine whether epigenetic DNA-me alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. We found that epigenetic DNA-me alterations at certain loci associated with glycemia persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a foundation for future studies of the epigenetic mechanisms underlying metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The biological mechanisms involved in the development of the disease are still poorly understood. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a possible explanation for the high prevalence of psychiatric disorders in alcoholic patients. This study may also help to understand the pathophysiology of the disease and to develop new therapeutic strategies.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor, 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and opens the door to the development of improved tomato cultivars with enhanced flavor. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the need to consider the full range of biodiversity loss and environmental warming effects on ecosystem functioning in order to understand the full extent of the threat they pose.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. It is divided into superficial and deep layers, and the superficial layers are subdivided into three sublayers. The superficial layers are thought to be important for the formation of grid cells, which are thought to be involved in the formation of spatial maps. However, the anatomical organization of the grid cells and their connections with other neurons in the superficial layers is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically organized, and their connections with other neurons are different from those of other neurons. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of grid cells and their connections in the superficial layers of MEC. They will help us to understand the function of MEC in spatial navigation and memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and endogenous factors. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine-containing nigral system is a major source of dopamine in the brain and is involved in the control of movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing dendrites of the nigral system form unusual arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending striosomal fibers and that these striosomal fibers, in turn, project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. These findings have implications for our understanding of the function of the dopamine-containing nigral system in health and disease.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is a specialized heart tissue that generates the heart rate. The SAN is composed of specialized cells called sinoatrial cells (SANCs), which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is regulated by a “clock” that controls the amount of calcium in the SAN cells. This calcium “clock” is composed of two parts: a membrane clock and a store clock. The membrane clock is composed of voltage-gated calcium channels, whereas the store clock is composed of a calcium sensor and a calcium channel. In this study, we found that the calcium sensor is expressed in the sinoatrial cells, and that it is important for the regulation of the heart rate. This study provides a new understanding of the regulation of the heart rate. This study also provides a new target for the treatment of heart disease.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA-mediated defense responses involves priming of JA accumulation and Si accumulation by JA and the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme that is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of single neurons. We show that the dynamics of these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. We propose that this mechanism is a fundamental component of language processing, and that it may be the substrate of short-term memory in the brain.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as siRNA to plants is a challenge due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can deliver biomolecules across the cell wall and that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant biotechnology.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can lead to harmful algal blooms and other ecological and economic impacts. The nutrient sources fueling these blooms are often unknown, however, because of the difficulty of measuring nutrient inputs to large water bodies. We show that small tributaries can be important sources of nutrients to large lakes, and that the nutrient inputs from small watersheds may be more bioavailable than those from larger watersheds. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include small watersheds, which may be the most cost-effective way to reduce coastal eutrophication. This approach could be applied to other large lakes and other water bodies that are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is made available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by rare combinations of forces. We propose that this behavior is a general feature of complex systems that are made to operate in a thermodynamic environment that is made available only to rare combinations of states.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the NMDA receptor disrupt its function and cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–induced changes in cortical microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We use a dynamic model of cortical microcircuitry to explain the effects of NMDAR-Ab on cortical microcircuitry and to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same parameters that are tolerated in the control condition can become critical in the presence of NMDAR-Ab. This may explain the wide range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Our findings may also help to explain the effects of other autoimmune encephalitis antibodies on the brain. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification, which could have had implications for the evolution of the biosphere. These results provide insights into the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming and can be used to inform our understanding of the current situation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced tropical deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies that can reduce tropical deforestation. Our findings also highlight the importance of rigorous monitoring of certification impacts. This is especially important for the RSPO, which has been criticized for its lack of transparency and accountability.

The exocytosis process is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and a potential drug target for diseases related to the exocytosis process. This study also offers a potential explanation for the evolutionarily conserved function of the exocyst complex in different kingdoms of life.

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes and two sexes only. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex determination is polygenic, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two female- and two male-determining alleles interact to produce four possible sexes. We find that polygenic sex determination results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a newly acquired sex determination allele creates additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoid lipofuscin and photogenerated reactive oxygen species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoid lipofuscin. We found that intracellular Fe levels, as reflected in transferrin receptor mRNA expression, were reduced in mice treated with the Fe chelator deferiprone. This reduction in Fe levels was associated with reduced levels of bisretinoid lipofuscin and reduced cell death in the retina. These findings indicate that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and other retinal diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the functioning of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla, specialized structures used for prey capture, is linked to the evolution of other parts of the siphonophore body. Our results suggest that the evolution of predatory specialization is not a dead end, and that specialization can be linked to the evolution of other parts of the body. This study contributes to understanding the evolution of predatory specialization, and its consequences for the functioning of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of hominin research. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand is particularly poor between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding is important for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human hand morphology. It also has implications for the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of modern humans and Neandertals.

Cancer cells have a number of metabolic adaptations that allow them to survive despite the presence of a tumor. One such metabolic adaptation is the ability to use serine as a one-carbon donor, which is essential for the synthesis of purine nucleotides. This study identifies a small-molecule inhibitor of serine metabolism that blocks tumor growth in a mouse model. The inhibitor is effective in a number of cancer cell lines, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cell lines that are deficient in glycine import. This study identifies a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is a particularly aggressive form of cancer, and suggests a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of this disease. The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the effects of environmental change on people’s diets. This approach can be used to test causal hypotheses and to make causal inferences in the presence of confounding and endogeneity. This study also highlights the importance of using multiple sources of data to test causal hypotheses. This study combines two-way fixed-effects regression analysis with covariate balancing generalized propensity score (CBGPS) weighting, which allowed for causal inferences to be made. This approach can be used to test causal hypotheses and to make causal inferences in the presence of confounding and endogeneity.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
